resources.string: The EU passed the Artificial Intelligence Act in 2024 to regulate the use and provision of AI systems. Despite the positive aspects of AI systems, they can also be used to spread misinformation and disinformation. This paper examines the technical implementation options for providers of AI systems to ensure compliance with the obligation to provide transparency for synthetically generated content. The spread of misinformation and disinformation on the internet is considered the greatest threat in the next two years.

This paper develops a proof of concept to investigate the practical implementation of the requirements of Article 50, Paragraphs 2 and 4 of the EU Intelligence Act. For this paper, the requirements are limited to image generation. Various methods for implementation are examined. In particular, implementation using the International Standard Content Code (ISCC) is examined in more detail. For this purpose, the procedure for generating the ISCC for images is disclosed and explained. Furthermore, the historical development of image generation is presented and its importance for the detection of synthetically generated content is highlighted. Finally, possible starting points for further development for the detection of generated audio, video, and text content are presented.

The International Standard Content Code (ISCC) is a method for identifying digital media content on the Internet and is certified as an ISO standard (ISO 24138:2024). Titusz Pan and the ISCC Foundation developed the ISCC in 2019, which supports a wide variety of digital media types such as audio, video, images, exts, and a variety of the most common file formats. When generating the ISCC, four hash values (units) are created, which together produce a 55-character character string (ISCC). By comparing the hash values of two different digital media, a statement can be made about their similarity.
